prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Defences to Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: If no obligation of confidence exists, a defendant is entitled to use or disclose the trade secrets of the plaintiff. Therefore, in order for information to be protected by the courts, the plaintiff must have impressed upon the defendant the confidentiality of the information.[1] However, even if the defendant was asked to maintain the confidentiality of the information, the plaintiff must still establish that the information was and remains confidential business information. Information does not become confidential simply because one states it to be so. In both Drake International Ltd. v. Miller[2] and Management Recruiters of Toronto Ltd. v. Bagg,[3] no obligation of confidence was imposed since the information was not truly confidential.

In S.N.S. Industrial Products Limited v. Omron Canada Inc.,[4] the defendant Omron operated in Canada as a manufacturer of industrial automation products. SNS was a distributor of Omron products between 1996 and 2015. Omron gave written notice to SNS of its intention to terminate the Distribution Agreement, effective sixty days thereafter. Omron subsequently gave notice to SNS that it was invoking the Distributorship Agreement to immediately terminate the Distributorship Agreement for cause. The immediate termination notice cited, as cause, an alleged breach by SNS of its obligations under the Distributorship Agreement to maintain adequate inventory and to provide continuous distribution and support services in the sales territory, as evidenced by the refusal of SNS to fill customers' orders for Omron product, including product that SNS had in stock, and the dissemination by SNS of a letter to its customers disparaging Omron stating, among other things, that Omron intended to transfer SNS' customers to other distributors who would provide less competitive pricing and lower service levels.[5]

Omron's motion for summary judgment seeking dismissal of SNS' action against it was granted. SNS pleaded that Omron misappropriated confidential information belonging to it. The confidential information that SNS alleged was conveyed to Omron consisted of the names of its customers and, in addition, its knowledge of the “technical, complex and automated nature of Omron products” which was such that “trained technical employees” were required to sell and service such products.[6]

Justice Broad observed that it was difficult to see how the “technical, complex and automated nature” of Omron's own products could constitute confidential information of SNS. Moreover, SNS had not established a basis by which the identity of customers who purchased Omron products was confidential to it. Paragraph 8(g) of the Distribution Agreement specifically provided that Omron shall be permitted to utilize information supplied by SNS under paragraphs 3(b) and 3(c), namely point-of-sale information and selling prices to SNS' customers and other reports relating to marketing and product development as Omron may reasonably request, to the extent necessary, in Omron's reasonable business judgment, to ensure that the needs of customers in the territory are met.[7]

In Justice Broad's view, there were no or insufficient particulars or evidence as to what confidential information Omron received, how it used or misused that information, how it benefited from so doing, and how SNS was damaged as a result. The claim for misappropriation of confidential information consisted of sweeping generalizations. SNS was required to put its “best foot forward” in response to the motion for summary judgment and the court was entitled to assume that the evidence led by SNS on the motion on this issue would be its evidence at trial. There was no triable issue with respect to SNS' claim for misappropriation of confidential information. There were no issues of credibility requiring a trial in relation to this claim.[8]

On appeal in S.N.S. Industrial Products Limited v. Omron Canada Inc.,[9] the plaintiff appealed from the summary judgement granted by the motion judge that dismissed the plaintiff's action. The Ontario Court of Appeal concluded that the motion judge properly concluded that there was no evidence to support the appellant's allegations of misuse of confidential information. The appellant's submission that other evidence might have been obtained if discoveries had been held completely misunderstood the principles surrounding summary judgment motions. All parties are required to put their best case forward and cannot avoid an adverse result by suggesting that if more opportunity is given, other information would be forthcoming.[10]

In Jane Doe 72511 v. Morgan,[11] the plaintiff sought default judgment against her former boyfriend for damages arising from his abusive behaviour towards her and his posting, without her knowledge and consent, of a sexually explicit video of her on a pornographic internet website. In June 2016, the Plaintiff learned through a friend that the Defendant had, without her knowledge or consent, posted a sexually explicit video of them on a pornography website. The video had been posted in March 2014 and was linked to ten other pornographic websites. The Plaintiff's face was clearly visible in the video while the Defendant's face was not. When confronted s about the video, the Defendant admitted that he uploaded it as revenge for the Plaintiff calling the police following an assault. Although the Plaintiff persuaded the website administrator to take the video down, it had by then been viewed over 60,000 times. It was impossible to know how many times it was downloaded and shared. The Plaintiff was haunted by the possibility that her son, employers, friends and potential romantic partners had seen or would see the video. The Plaintiff was not a minor at the time, and consented to the making of the video. She did not however consent to its disclosure to other people or its posting on the internet.[12]

The judge considered whether the Plaintiff could claim for claim for breach of confidence even though this cause of action was not mentioned in her statement of claim. Relying on Watson v. TrojanOne Ltd., 2016 CarswellOnt 6479, 2016 ONSC 2740, the Plaintiff submitted that this omission did not matter so long as the constituent elements of the claim was alleged. The judge was not sure that Watson v. TrojanOne Ltd. stood for the broad proposition that a plaintiff may seek default judgment for causes of action that are not mentioned in the statement of claim. Even if it did, any claim for this additional causes of action could not succeed because she had not alleged all of the essential elements of the cause of action. In a breach of confidence claim, a plaintiff must allege that confidential information was imparted in circumstances “importing an obligation of confidence”. In her statement of claim, the Plaintiff did not provide any explanation of how the Defendant came into the possession of the sexually explicit video. She simply alleged that the Defendant uploaded the video to a pornographic website without her knowledge or consent. This was sufficient for the purpose of an action for public disclosure of private information, but not for an action for breach of confidence.[13]
